title: Choosing the Right Math App for Your Child: A Parent's Guide
description: How to evaluate math learning apps and choose one that actually helps your child learn, not just play.
imageAlt: Child using math learning app on tablet

content.intro: Hundreds of math apps exist. Some are genuinely educational. Others are games with math wallpaper. Here's how to tell the difference.

sections.text: What Makes a Good Math App

rows: Meets child where they are, not too easy or hard
Shows parents and kids what's being learned
Targets specific skills, not random practice

items: More rewards than math (90% collecting coins, 10% learning)
No wrong answer feedback (just says "try again")
No parent dashboard or progress reports
Ads or in-app purchases that interrupt learning

sections.text: Best for: Fact fluency. Look for spaced repetition and adaptive difficulty.
Best for: Understanding "why." Look for visual models, manipulatives, and explanations.
Best for: Application and engagement. Make sure math is central, not incidental.
Best for: Comprehensive learning. Useful if you're supplementing or homeschooling.

items: What specific skills does my child need?
Does this app target those skills?
Can I see what my child is learning?
Is there a progression or is it random?
How much screen time is appropriate?
Is there teacher/classroom integration if needed?

sections.text: Try before you buy. Most quality apps have free trials. Use the trial to see if your child actually engages with the math, not just the games or rewards.
Even the best app won't replace:
Apps work best as supplements to, not replacements for, real-world learning.

faq.question: Are paid apps better than free ones?
faq.answer: Often, yes. Free apps typically rely on ads or data collection. Paid apps (or subscription models) can focus on quality. But there are exceptions in both directions.

faq.question: How much screen time for math apps is okay?
faq.answer: 15-20 minutes daily is often ideal for focused math practice. Longer sessions tend to show diminishing returns.

faq.question: Should I use multiple math apps?
faq.answer: One good app used consistently is better than many apps used sporadically. Too many apps fragments learning and makes progress tracking difficult.
